cards.back: Translating real-world phenomena into equations, variables, and assumptions. Balances accuracy with computational tractability. The essential first step before any computation.
Physical System →(assumptions)→ Mathematical Model →(algorithm)→ Computational Solution →(validation)→ Prediction. Each arrow involves choices.

cards.front: Simple model vs. elaborate model — when to use each?
cards.back: Simple: few parameters, fast, approximate — good for quick insights and design exploration. Elaborate: many parameters, slow, high fidelity — good for final verification and predictive simulation.

cards.front: List 5 elementary assumptions for a simple rectifier circuit.
cards.back: 1. Zero parasitic L/C/R in wires. 2. Low frequency. 3. No EMI. 4. Reasonable voltage/current range. 5. Fixed resistance (no thermal variation).

cards.front: Write the load line equation for a circuit with source Vs and resistance (r+R).
cards.back: I = (−1/(r+R))·V_D + V_S/(r+R). When I = 0: V_D = Vs. When V_D = 0: I = Vs/(r+R). Straight line in V_D-I plane.

cards.front: What determines the operating point in a diode circuit?
cards.back: The intersection of the load line (circuit constraint) and the diode I-V characteristic (device model). Different diode models give different operating points.
Comparing model predictions against measurements, higher-fidelity models, or known analytical solutions. If validation fails, refine the model (not the algorithm).

cards.front: Why can a perfect algorithm give wrong answers?
cards.back: Because the algorithm solves the model, not reality. If the model is wrong (bad assumptions, missing physics), the perfectly computed answer to the wrong equation is still wrong.

cards.front: State the golden rule of mathematical modeling.
cards.back: The best model is the simplest one that answers your question accurately enough. Unnecessary complexity wastes computation and can introduce errors without improving answers.

cards.front: At what frequency do wire parasitics become significant?
cards.back: Above ~100 MHz for typical PCB traces. A 1 cm wire at 1 GHz has ~60 Ω of inductive reactance. At DC/low frequency, this is negligible.
